text: The Firefox logo is not a fox. It's a Red Panda, which is also called a "Firefox."
The first computer mouse, invented by Douglas Engelbart in 1964, was made of wood.
The word "robot" comes from the Czech word "robota," which means "forced labor" or "drudgery."
The original name for Windows was "Interface Manager." Bill Gates was convinced to change it.
A group of scientists at Cambridge invented the first webcam in 1991 to monitor a coffee pot so they wouldn't waste a trip if it was empty.
The name "Google" originated from a misspelling of the mathematical term "googol" (10^100).
Email was invented in 1971, which predates the World Wide Web (invented in 1989/1990).
The sound you hear when the original Xbox boots up contains snippets from actual NASA space missions.
Nokia started as a paper mill, then made rubber boots, tires, and toilet paper before getting into electronics.
The CAPS LOCK key is the most universally hated button in IT.
The first 1GB hard drive in 1980 was the size of a refrigerator, weighed over 500 pounds, and cost $40,000.
Your average keyboard contains 400 times more bacteria than a toilet seat. (Go clean your keyboard!)
The reason we call unrequested electronic messages "Spam" is due to a Monty Python sketch where a group of Vikings sing the word repeatedly.
Every iPhone advertisement is set to the time 9:41 AM, the exact time Steve Jobs unveiled the first iPhone in 2007.
Mark Zuckerberg is red-green colorblind, which is why blue dominates the Facebook color scheme.
The longest word you can type using only the top row of a QWERTY keyboard is "Typewriter."
The first commercial hard drive, the IBM 350 Disk File (1956), stored just 5 megabytes (MB) of data.
The Internet is not the same as the World Wide Web; the Internet is the physical network, and the Web is the collection of pages and links (like an ocean vs. the ships on it).
The world's first programmer was a woman named Ada Lovelace in the mid-1800s.
Domain name registration was free until 1995.
NASA’s internal network runs at speeds 13,000 times faster than the average home internet connection.
Google rents out goats to "mow" the lawns at their Mountain View headquarters.
The world’s first-ever computer was the ENIAC, built in 1945, which weighed 27 tons and took up 1,800 square feet.
Typing "askew" into a Google search bar will tilt the results page.
The "@" symbol in email addresses was chosen by Ray Tomlinson because it was not common in names and would avoid confusion.
The world’s most popular password for years has consistently been "123456" or "password."
Samsung started in 1938 as a grocery store and noodle-making business.
When using a computer, the average person blinks only 7 times per minute, compared to the normal rate of 20.
The total weight of the entire Internet (the electrons in motion that make it work) has been estimated to be roughly the weight of a single strawberry (about 50 grams).
The first video uploaded to YouTube was titled "Me at the Zoo" on April 23, 2005.
The first item sold on eBay was a broken laser pointer for $14.83. The buyer was a collector of broken laser pointers.
The concept of a computer came long before electricity: Charles Babbage designed the mechanical Analytical Engine in the 1830s.
Nintendo was founded in 1889, selling playing cards (Hanafuda).
The first computer virus, called "Creeper" (1971), was harmless and only displayed the message: "I'M THE CREEPER: CATCH ME IF YOU CAN."
"Voice.com" is one of the most expensive domain names ever sold, going for $30 million in 2019.
There are currently more connected devices (computers, phones, IoT gadgets) on Earth than there are people.
A 75-year-old woman in Georgia once accidentally severed a fiber optic cable while scavenging for copper, cutting off internet to all of Armenia and parts of Georgia for hours.
The founders of the biggest tech companies often have no college degree (Bill Gates, Steve Jobs, Mark Zuckerberg).
Ctrl+Alt+Del was originally intended to be a user-friendly feature by David Bradley, not a system-reset command.
The first digital camera (1975) was the size of a toaster, took 23 seconds to record a photo, and the image was in black and white at 0.01 megapixels.
The iconic Twitter bird logo is named "Larry," after basketball legend Larry Bird.
The Bluetooth logo is a combination of two Norse runes: H (for Harald) and B (for Bluetooth), representing Harald Bluetooth, a Danish king.
The average life expectancy of a floppy disk is 3 to 5 years.
MySpace accidentally deleted almost all music and photos uploaded to the site between 2003 and 2015 during a server migration.
The first cell phone was a Motorola DynaTAC 8000x (1983). It weighed two pounds and cost nearly $4,000.
The term "Firewall" comes from the physical barriers used to prevent a fire from spreading from one part of a building to another.
A single Google search uses more computational power than the entire Apollo 11 moon mission had available.
CAPTCHA stands for "Completely Automated Public Turing test to tell Computers and Humans Apart."
Only about 8% of the world's currency is physical money; the rest is stored digitally.
The biggest computer crash in history was the Y2K Bug... which was completely anticlimactic thanks to programmers working overtime.
The first online order was a CD by the band Ten Summoner's Tales in 1994.
The phrase "You've Got Mail!" was voiced by the husband of a programmer who worked on AOL.
The smallest unit of memory that can store a piece of information is a bit (binary digit: 0 or 1).
The world’s first website, created by Tim Berners-Lee in 1991, is still online (info.cern.ch).
The programming language Python was named after the British comedy group Monty Python, not the snake.
The earliest known analogue computer is the Antikythera mechanism, an ancient Greek device dating back to around 100 BC.
Before founding Apple, Steve Jobs worked for Atari.
The total number of mobile devices now exceeds the world's population.
The official mascot for the BSD operating system is a smiling, waving cartoon devil named Beastie.
The original purpose of YouTube was reportedly a video dating site called "Tune In Hook Up."
The fear of computers is called logizomechanophobia.
The average computer technician's diet consists mainly of caffeine, stale donuts, and the cold dread of an upcoming Monday.
An average of 6,000 tweets are sent every second.
The number of people who fall for a phishing scam is surprisingly high because the scammers only need to be right once.
The first ever emoticon was proposed by Scott Fahlman in 1982: :-)
The original Apple logo featured Sir Isaac Newton sitting under a tree.
Amazon was originally going to be named "Cadabra" (as in Abracadabra), but the name sounded too much like "Cadaver" over the phone.
Linux was created by Linus Torvalds in 1991 as a hobby.
The first recorded public broadcast on television was in 1925 and showed a rotating puppet.
The computer game Tetris was the first video game to be exported from the Soviet Union to the US.
Most IT professionals prefer to fix problems with a single, perfectly timed reboot.
The programming language COBOL (Common Business-Oriented Language) is still used in many old banking and government systems.
The first domain registered was symbolics.com on March 15, 1985.
The computer's internal clock is often called the RTC (Real-Time Clock).
The term "algorithm" is named after the 9th-century Persian mathematician Muhammad ibn Musa al-Khwarizmi.
The most popular search query on the Bing search engine is "Google."
The first person to receive a computer-generated voice message was Queen Elizabeth II in 1976.
The average lifespan of a modern computer fan is about 50,000 hours.
The longest currently registered domain name is 63 characters long and belongs to a small village in Wales.
Only about 5% of the internet's content is considered "publicly indexable" by search engines; the rest is the Deep Web.
The "refresh" button on your browser is the technological equivalent of blowing on a video game cartridge.
The technology that led to Wi-Fi was originally developed by an Australian astronomer to detect exploding black holes.
The first computer game was Spacewar!, developed in 1962 by MIT students.
The most common lie in IT is, "I didn't change anything, it just stopped working!"
The first piece of music ever played by a computer was "God Save the Queen" in 1951.
The first image uploaded to the World Wide Web was a photo of a comedy band called Les Horribles Cernettes (created by CERN employees).
The IBM 5100 (1975) was a portable computer that weighed 55 pounds.
The first-ever computer mouse only cost about $20 in parts to make.
The person who invented the GIF pronounced it with a soft 'G' (Jif), like the peanut butter.
Quantum computing uses qubits (q) which can be 0, 1, or both simultaneously (superposition).
The most difficult part of debugging is convincing yourself that the error is your fault.
The term "Trojan horse" comes from the ancient Greek story of the siege of Troy.
Bill Gates' first company, Traf-O-Data, failed.
The first advertisement for a mobile phone was printed in a magazine in 1973.
Despite all the progress in AI, you are still required to click on a tiny box to prove you are not a robot.
The QWERTY keyboard layout was designed to slow down typists to prevent mechanical jamming.
The first computer bug was an actual moth found trapped in a relay of the Harvard Mark II in 1947.
DNS (Domain Name System) is often called the 'phonebook of the Internet'.
The Apple I computer sold for $666.66 because Steve Wozniak liked repeating digits and found it easier to type.
Java was originally named "Oak" after an oak tree that stood outside the office of its creator, James Gosling.
The term "Bug" was used by Thomas Edison to describe technical glitches in 1878, nearly 70 years before the famous "moth in the relay" incident.
Nintendo owns the rights to two Super Mario porn parodies (titled Super Hornio Brothers), which they bought solely to prevent them from being distributed.
Space Invaders gets faster as you kill aliens because the original processor could finally render the remaining sprites faster as the load decreased.
The "Save" icon (a floppy disk) is now recognized by younger generations only as the "Save button," with many not knowing it depicts a physical object.
Unix time begins on January 1, 1970 (the Epoch). If you see a date glitch to Dec 31, 1969, it's because the timestamp value is -1 or 0 (adjusted for time zones).
Hewlett-Packard (HP) was founded in a garage. In 1939, Bill Hewlett and Dave Packard flipped a coin to decide whether the company would be called Hewlett-Packard or Packard-Hewlett.
Pixar started as the "Computer Division" of Lucasfilm before Steve Jobs bought it. Their primary product was originally a high-end computer called the Pixar Image Computer.
The first banner ad appeared on Wired.com (then HotWired) in 1994 for AT&T. It had a 44% click-through rate.
Microsoft saved Apple from bankruptcy in 1997 with a $150 million investment.
The code for Apollo 11 was written by a team led by Margaret Hamilton. The printed stack of code stood nearly as tall as she did.
The QR Code was invented by Denso Wave in 1994 to track automotive parts. Its design was inspired by the black and white pieces on a Go board.
GPS relies on Einstein's Theory of Relativity. Without adjusting for the time dilation caused by the satellites' speed and gravity, GPS accuracy would drift by miles every day.
Tim Berners-Lee apologized for the double slash (//) in URLs, admitting it was unnecessary and wasted paper/ink over the decades.
C++ is named "C plus plus" because in programming, ++ is the operator to increment a value by 1. It is literally "one better than C."
JavaScript was created in just 10 days by Brendan Eich.
JavaScript is not related to Java. The name was a marketing ploy to piggyback on Java's popularity at the time.
SQL was originally named SEQUEL (Structured English Query Language), but the name was changed due to a trademark dispute.
There is a programming language called Whitespace that uses only spaces, tabs, and line breaks. The code looks like a blank page.
There is a programming language called ArnoldC where all commands are one-liners from Arnold Schwarzenegger movies.
GitHub's mascot is a "octocat"—a cat with five octopus legs (though commonly drawn with just the tail visible).
The "Hello, World!" tradition comes from the 1978 book The C Programming Language by Kernighan and Ritchie.
HTML is technically a markup language, not a programming language, as it structures text but lacks logic like loops or variables.
Perl is often nicknamed "The Swiss Army Chainsaw" of scripting languages.
Scratch, the kids' coding language, was developed by MIT Media Lab.
null (the concept of a null reference) was called a "billion-dollar mistake" by its inventor, Tony Hoare, due to the number of system crashes it has caused.
Vim vs. Emacs is one of the oldest rivalries in computing, often referred to as the "Editor War."
PHP originally stood for "Personal Home Page". It now stands for "PHP: Hypertext Preprocessor" (a recursive acronym).
The Konami Code (Up, Up, Down, Down, Left, Right, Left, Right, B, A) works on many websites, including some banks and Buzzfeed, often triggering Easter eggs.
Moore's Law is not a law of physics; it is an observation that the number of transistors on a microchip doubles about every two years.
The gold in electronic waste (e-waste) is more concentrated than in high-grade gold ore from a mine.
Hard drives have a filtered air intake hole. If you cover it, the drive will eventually fail because the read/write head relies on air pressure to float above the disk.
USB was designed to be non-reversible because making it reversible would have doubled the cost, which the inventors feared would kill the technology's adoption.
The Raspberry Pi was originally intended to sell only 1,000 units to help students learn coding. It has now sold over 40 million units.
The US Air Force once built a supercomputer out of 1,760 PlayStation 3 consoles because it was cheaper than buying standard server parts.
A Zip Bomb is a malicious file that is small (kilobytes) when compressed but expands to petabytes when unzipped, crashing the system.
The Intel 4004 (1971) was the first commercially available microprocessor.
Modern CPUs are made of silicon, which is extracted from common sand.
Water cooling computers involves using distilled water mixed with biocides to prevent algae growth inside your PC.
Mechanical keyboards are preferred by gamers and typists because each key has an individual physical switch, offering tactile feedback.
OLED screens can suffer from "burn-in," where a static image (like a news ticker or health bar) remains permanently visible as a ghost image.
The noise a dial-up modem made was actually the sound of the two computers "handshaking"—negotiating protocols and speeds.
A Faraday Cage can block all wireless signals. Some secure government rooms are built as Faraday cages to prevent eavesdropping.
The 404 Error was not named after "Room 404" at CERN. It simply follows the HTTP error code numbering scheme.
Kevin Mitnick, once the world's most wanted hacker, served 5 years in prison and later became a highly paid security consultant.
"Phreaking" was the precursor to hacking, involving the manipulation of phone systems to get free calls (often using a whistle found in Cap'n Crunch cereal boxes).
Wiki is a Hawaiian word meaning "quick."
The first SMS ever sent was "Merry Christmas" in 1992.
Cloudflare uses a wall of lava lamps in their San Francisco office to generate random numbers for encryption.
Amazon owned a patent for "1-Click" buying until 2017. Apple licensed this patent from Amazon for use in iTunes.
Incognito Mode does not hide your browsing history from your ISP or your employer; it only prevents your browser from saving the history locally.
The "Dark Web" requires special software like Tor to access, whereas the "Deep Web" is simply anything not indexed by Google (like private emails).
Stuxnet was a computer worm discovered in 2010 that physically destroyed nuclear centrifuges in Iran by spinning them out of control.
"Salt" in cryptography is random data added to a password before hashing it, ensuring that two users with the same password have different hashes.
SQL Injection is a common hacking technique where an attacker types code into a login field to trick the database into granting access.
DDOS stands for "Distributed Denial of Service," working like a traffic jam where thousands of requests crash a website.
VPN stands for Virtual Private Network.
Tor stands for "The Onion Router," named because it has layers of encryption like an onion.
Google pays Mozilla (Firefox) hundreds of millions of dollars a year to remain the default search engine in the Firefox browser.
Steve Jobs famously denied that he was the father of his daughter, Lisa, for years, yet named an early Apple computer the Apple Lisa.
Netflix accounts for approximately 15% of the total downstream volume of traffic across the entire internet globally.
Tesla cars run on a custom Linux-based operating system.
Jeff Bezos originally wanted to name Amazon "Relentless." If you type relentless.com into your browser, it still redirects to Amazon.
The Twitter fail whale was originally an illustration of a peaceful whale being lifted by birds.
Apple’s terms and conditions prohibit you from using their products to create nuclear missiles or biological weapons.
Mark Zuckerberg has a tape over his laptop's webcam and microphone jack, as seen in a background photo posted on Facebook.
Android versions were named alphabetically after desserts (Cupcake, Donut, Eclair...) until Android 10 broke the tradition.
Steve Wozniak is still technically an employee of Apple and receives a stipend, despite not having an active role for decades.
Bill Gates has been known to wash his own dishes every night, finding it meditative.
Elon Musk bought x.com in 1999, sold it to PayPal, and bought it back in 2017 for "sentimental value" before using it for Twitter.
The Google Doodles started when Larry Page and Sergey Brin drew a stick figure behind the logo to indicate they were at the Burning Man festival.
Samsung manufactures the screens used in many iPhones. Apple and Samsung are both partners and rivals.
The Corrupted Blood incident in World of Warcraft (2005) was a virtual pandemic that epidemiologists studied to understand real-world disease spread.
In the original Super Mario Bros., the clouds and the bushes use the exact same sprite; only the color palette is different.
The Pac-Man "Kill Screen" happens at level 256 because the 8-bit integer used to count levels overflows.
Doom (1993) has been ported to run on pregnancy tests, ATMs, thermostats, and even inside the game Minecraft.
Unreal Engine, now used for filmmaking (like The Mandalorian), was originally built just for the game Unreal in 1998.
Minecraft is the best-selling video game of all time.
Steam was created by Valve because they wanted a way to automatically update their games like Counter-Strike.
The highest possible score in Snake (the Nokia version) involves filling the entire screen, at which point the game ends.
Speedrunners utilize glitches like "wall clipping" to beat games in minutes that usually take hours.
The term "AFK" (Away From Keyboard) originated in the chat rooms of the 1990s.
Rubber Duck Debugging is a method where a programmer explains their code line-by-line to a rubber duck to find errors.
The Year 2038 Problem is the next "Y2K," where 32-bit systems will run out of seconds to count from 1970.
The Command key (⌘) on Mac keyboards is a "Place of Interest" symbol used on road signs in Sweden and other Nordic countries.
The Power symbol is a stylized combination of the binary "1" (on) and "0" (off).
A "Nibble" is half a byte (4 bits).
The ISO 8601 standard is the internationally accepted way to write dates (YYYY-MM-DD) to avoid confusion between formats.
Ctrl+C and Ctrl+V (Cut and Paste) were popularized by Larry Tesler at Apple/Xerox PARC.
Copy-pasting from Stack Overflow is such a common developer habit that on April Fool's Day, the site once added a limit to how many times you could copy code.
Comic Sans is recommended for dyslexic readers because the irregular letter shapes make them easier to distinguish.
Lorem Ipsum text is scrambled Latin from a passage by Cicero written in 45 BC.
Bluetooth devices are named "Master" and "Slave" in the technical protocol, though the industry is moving toward "Central" and "Peripheral."
Deep Blue was the first computer to defeat a reigning world chess champion (Garry Kasparov) in 1997.
Watson, an IBM computer, defeated the two greatest Jeopardy! champions in 2011.
AlphaGo defeated Lee Sedol at Go in 2016, a feat AI experts thought was still a decade away due to the game's complexity.
Imposter Syndrome is reportedly higher in the tech industry than almost any other field due to the rapid pace of change.
